paper_title.ja: ミューズ教育の研究〔Ⅷ〕―ミューズ教育思想の歴史的概観―
paper_title.en: Studies on 'Musische Erziehung' in Germany (Part VIII) : A Historical Survey of the Thought of Musische Erziehung

description.ja: Because there have already been presented many treatises on the history of thought of 'Musische Erziehung (education)'-which is peculiar to modern Germany-in this series, this treatise will sum up these results, namely, survey this history. The summary is as follows. Deriving from Schiller's Aesthetic Education Theory and preserving the basic direction of his theory, which was a concrete expression of 'Aesthetic Humanism' in the German classical period, 'Musische Erziehung' arose directly from the Art Education Movement around 1900, and was influenced by the Youth Movement, Expressionism and Nietzche's philosophy of life behind both at the beginning of the 20th century. It took the clear form around 1930, was transformed by the Nazis, but revived soon after the war in 1949, and flourished in the 1950's. It took spiritual nourishment from the philosophy of 'play' (e. g. Huizinga) or 'leisure' (e. g. Pieper) and from anthropological pedagogics (e. g. Bollnow), though it was criticized for many positions from the last years of the 1950's to the 1960's, but defended because of the necessity of 'Musische Erziehung' until around 1980. Thus, the thought of 'Musische Erziehung' consistently had as its foundation the concept of 'Aesthetic-Political Education' which was based on the idea of aesthetic communication in Schiller's Aesthetic Education Theory.
description.en: Because there have already been presented many treatises on the history of thought of 'Musische Erziehung (education)'-which is peculiar to modern Germany-in this series, this treatise will sum up these results, namely, survey this history. The summary is as follows. Deriving from Schiller's Aesthetic Education Theory and preserving the basic direction of his theory, which was a concrete expression of 'Aesthetic Humanism' in the German classical period, 'Musische Erziehung' arose directly from the Art Education Movement around 1900, and was influenced by the Youth Movement, Expressionism and Nietzche's philosophy of life behind both at the beginning of the 20th century. It took the clear form around 1930, was transformed by the Nazis, but revived soon after the war in 1949, and flourished in the 1950's. It took spiritual nourishment from the philosophy of 'play' (e. g. Huizinga) or 'leisure' (e. g. Pieper) and from anthropological pedagogics (e. g. Bollnow), though it was criticized for many positions from the last years of the 1950's to the 1960's, but defended because of the necessity of 'Musische Erziehung' until around 1980. Thus, the thought of 'Musische Erziehung' consistently had as its foundation the concept of 'Aesthetic-Political Education' which was based on the idea of aesthetic communication in Schiller's Aesthetic Education Theory.

paper_title.en: Studies on `Musische Erziehung' in Germany (Part VII) : Structual Relationships among the Concepts in the Thought of Musische Erziehung

description.ja: It was already demonstrated in part VI of this series, that the fundamental attitude of `Musische Erziehung (education)' which is peculiar to modern Germany and is derived from F.v.Schiller's Aesthetic Education Theory, is criticism of the dual principles of objective rationalism and egoistic expression in modern times, namely a criticism of the age. Thus, this thought made the conception of `Aesthetic-Political Education' a soluti on to this problematic duality. And the foundation of thought of `Musische Erziehng' was consolidated more positively through the notions of the `totality' of the humane being, aesthetic `play' , `leisure' , `inner life' and `community' which appeared in succession in the history of this thought. In `Musische Erziehung' these five are bifunctional concepts including both method and aim. Therefore, in this treatise I will consider the historical sources, contents and mutual relations of these five concepts, and make clear by this work the structural relationships among these in the thought of `Musische Erziehung'. Through this analysis we can grasp fully the core of this thought.
description.en: It was already demonstrated in part VI of this series, that the fundamental attitude of `Musische Erziehung (education)' which is peculiar to modern Germany and is derived from F.v.Schiller's Aesthetic Education Theory, is criticism of the dual principles of objective rationalism and egoistic expression in modern times, namely a criticism of the age. Thus, this thought made the conception of `Aesthetic-Political Education' a soluti on to this problematic duality. And the foundation of thought of `Musische Erziehng' was consolidated more positively through the notions of the `totality' of the humane being, aesthetic `play' , `leisure' , `inner life' and `community' which appeared in succession in the history of this thought. In `Musische Erziehung' these five are bifunctional concepts including both method and aim. Therefore, in this treatise I will consider the historical sources, contents and mutual relations of these five concepts, and make clear by this work the structural relationships among these in the thought of `Musische Erziehung'. Through this analysis we can grasp fully the core of this thought.

paper_title.en: Studies on 'Musische Erziehung' in Germany (Part VI) : Das Musische (The Things Musical) and Political Education

description.ja: Most of the advocates of 'Musische Erziehung (education)' which is peculiar to modern Germany look to F.v.Schiller (1759-1805), a humanist of the German classical period, for their thoretical foundation in Aesthetic Education Theory. Schiller thought that Aesthetic Eduacation can free a man from both his material desires and his rational constraints, so that it can cultivate a man into a humane being. Namely, he had a political intention. His concrete method was to build communities with humane freedom through the aesthetic communication (beautiful social relatiohs). In this treatise I show this by quotations from many works on 'Musische Erziehung' between the 1840's and the 1970's and by my analyses of them. Incidentally, 'Das Musische' means not only the Things Musical, but also the aesthetic-artistic sense of persons too. Therefore, we can think that 'Musische Erziehung' is a political way to create a free society through social relations based on the sense of 'Das Musische'.
description.en: Most of the advocates of 'Musische Erziehung (education)' which is peculiar to modern Germany look to F.v.Schiller (1759-1805), a humanist of the German classical period, for their thoretical foundation in Aesthetic Education Theory. Schiller thought that Aesthetic Eduacation can free a man from both his material desires and his rational constraints, so that it can cultivate a man into a humane being. Namely, he had a political intention. His concrete method was to build communities with humane freedom through the aesthetic communication (beautiful social relatiohs). In this treatise I show this by quotations from many works on 'Musische Erziehung' between the 1840's and the 1970's and by my analyses of them. Incidentally, 'Das Musische' means not only the Things Musical, but also the aesthetic-artistic sense of persons too. Therefore, we can think that 'Musische Erziehung' is a political way to create a free society through social relations based on the sense of 'Das Musische'.

paper_title.ja: ミューズ教育の研究〔V〕-1933年前後のミューズ的美術教育思想-
paper_title.en: Studies on "Musische Erziehung" in Germany(Part V) : Theories of Art Education and Thought of Musische Erziehung at around 1993

description.ja: This paper examines the two different trends of thought(political and historical)in certain art educators in Germany when the Nazis came to power in 1933. Sometimes they assimilated Nazi ideology of "German National Education" in order to preserve art education in the schools. At other times they propounded the historical tradition(which began with the Art {s} Education Congresses of 1901-1905)of "Musische Erziehung[Education in Things Musical]" with its aim of "awaking and fostering the creative power(of the Muses)inherent in every Man".
description.en: This paper examines the two different trends of thought(political and historical)in certain art educators in Germany when the Nazis came to power in 1933. Sometimes they assimilated Nazi ideology of "German National Education" in order to preserve art education in the schools. At other times they propounded the historical tradition(which began with the Art {s} Education Congresses of 1901-1905)of "Musische Erziehung[Education in Things Musical]" with its aim of "awaking and fostering the creative power(of the Muses)inherent in every Man".
